title: Identifying two simple serif designs...
content:
Hi guys,

Can anyone help me identify the two fonts from these logos...

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071208063421im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/personafire_4490.gif)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071208063421im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/boxbound_logo_3752.jpg)

Thanks for your time,

Nat

 [‹ Does anyone know what type face Snellen Charts are. (eye exam chart)](http://web.archive.org/web/20071208063421/http:/www.typophile.com/node/38819 "Go to previous forum topic") [I need help please ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071208063421/http:/www.typophile.com/node/38829 "Go to next forum topic")
author: The White Lion

comments.content: Hmm, yeah that was fast matching. Thank you so much. Any ideas for the boxbound design?
I’d say custom for boxhound, but maybe someone else will come up with an ID.

I agree that boxbound is custom, thought it may be based on [Horatio](http://web.archive.org/web/20071208063421/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/elsner_flake/horatio_light/?sample_text=boxbound&sample_size=60&acs_p=1&acs_pt=24&acs=1).

Hmm, I can see how it comes from Horatio. Thank you for your insight. It was particularly the “n”/”u” that I was interested in, but that seems to be the customised part if it comes from Horatio. Oh well. Thanks for your help Jan and Stephen.

The angled terminals lead me to believe it’s [ITC Kabel Book](http://web.archive.org/web/20071208063421/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/itc/itc_kabel_book/?sample_text=boxbound&sample_size=36&acs_p=1&acs_pt=24&acs=1) with the ’b’ flipped horizontally as a ’d’, and some widening of the ’u’ and ’n’.

- Lex
